Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2009 09:25AM jancie wrote: Great thread and so glad Mamie2 that you bumped it up! I had a SLN biopsy done about 2.5 weeks ago.  I have a little bit of lumpiness (hard) under my incision but that feels like more of scar tissue thing going on so I am lightly massaging that area.  However, I do have that "cording thing" going on where I have a tight tendon that is sticking out and highly visible under my arm pit.  I am attending a weekly lymphedema exercise class - just being proactive, I don't have lymphedema.  I showed the instructor my arm pit and she said that it was caused by doing too much so soon after surgery.  I told her that I wasn't doing to much, heck I stayed in bed for 3 days straight on pain meds sleeping 18 hours a day, etc. I guess when I felt I was really not doing anything, vacuuming, etc. that in fact I was doing too much and the key she said was that I was doing things that lifted my arm above my head higher than my shoulder.  She said to not lift my arm upright - to keep it at 90% - hard to explain but take your elbow and put it straight out to your side, it is no more than that height that my lower arm should be at any given time for the next 2 to 3 weeks and that will help soften that tight tendon. Going back to the "I am not really doing anything" just after I got diagnosed with BC, I worked at a horse barn doing 8 to 9 hours daily of hard intensive labor.  So to me, grooming my huge horse for one hour because she rolled in the mud yesterday was "not doing much" - however that 1/2 hour of using my left arm high above my head (I am really short and my horse is REALLY tall) aggravated that tendon and tightened it up. I don't want lymphedema and I know that it can flare up even years from now so I am going to do everything possible to be proactive and follows this instructor's advice 100%.

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2009 04:35AM jancie wrote: A bone scan is designed to specifically look at the bones in your body to see if the cancer has progressed there as typically the cancer will spread to your bones before spreading to your organs. A petscan looks at all of your individual organs, kidney, stomach, liver, lungs, brain, etc. My doctor did not order a petscan since my bone scan came out clean. And I just got a report that my lymph nodes are clean also - I had a SLN biopsy done yesterday.
Posts.Title: IDC and concern about bones momwholovessoccer Member_of_the_Club

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2012 08:30AM jancie wrote: ns- take a breath - one at a time.  This is truly overwhelming.  I am glad that you are here for support as these women are just wonderful. It is not uncommon to have chemo first especially since you have a 5 CM area.  The good thing is that by doing chemo first - the oncologist can determine how well your body responds to chemo.  If your mass shrinks down alot during chemo then you know that your body is responding well. I had a 4 CM mass and had chemo first.  When it came time to do the lumpectomy the surgeon couldn't even feel my lump anymore.  By the 2nd chemo treatment he could already tell the lump was shrinking. Do you know if you are ER, PR postive or negative?  Her2 status?  Grade?  These answers would be on your pathology report.  Your oncologist will use that information to determine treatment. Once you do get a treatment plan put in place - I promise you - you will feel much better emotionally.

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2010 10:21PM jancie wrote: Weesa - I typically stay out of the Stage III forum but wanted to share with you what worked for me. There was a time when Ambien and valium quit working and I was lucky to sleep 3 to 4 hours a night.  After 3 weeks and being totally exhausted the doctors at the cancer center prescribed Mirtazapine for me.  It comes in I believe 15 mg tablets.  It is an anti-depressant IF you take the entire dosage but if you split the pill in half then it acts like a sleep aid.  Believe me, I was taking cocktails of Lortabs, valium, and whatever I could get my hands on and still couldn't sleep. The problem with Mirtazapine is that you will want to sleep for 12 hours straight so if you get a prescription for it - think aboiut taking it the first time on a Friday night or any night where you can sleep in the next day.  It did wonders for me!!! I am now able to sleep on Ambien or valium again but while undergoing chemo - neither one of them worked for me. Just don't ever combine Ambien and Valium.

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2009 01:57PM jancie wrote: I started rads 3 months after chemo - by the third day I was wiped out.  I ended up sleeping 12-14 hours a day.  I could barely move on most days.  The fatigue was much worse than chemo.  Looking back, chemo made me feel so bad I didn't want to do anything.  With rads, I felt great other than the fact that I COULDN'T do anything.  I got through it by telling myself I only had to complete 2 tasks each day and as long as I did those two tasks then I did enough.  Those tasks were simple such as running a couple loads of laundry and paying bills on one day, vacuuming and cooking the next day, etc.  I set my expectations very low so that I wouldn't get depressed with the fact that I wasn't really doing much and it worked!

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2009 09:24PM jancie wrote: My tumor is 4CM and my breast surgeon said that he would not do a lumpectomy due to the size of the tumor and the small size of my breasts.  He said that they would not be able to reconstruct my breast and have it come out the way I would like for it to because he would have to take so much breast tissue out to get clear margins that I would lose most of my breast anyways. Since AT that time I was uncomfortable with getting a masectomy he suggested that I do chemo first to shrink down the tumor (if possible) to a much smaller size. He ordered an MRI and bone scan.  The MRI came out with disappointing results as it looks like there is something going on with my other breast. My question to your surgeon would be how much breast tissue is he going to remove and if you are opting for plastic surgery afterwards would the results be satisfactory to you? Have you had an MRI done?  If not, I would ask for one since it is a more advanced test than the mammogram and will clearly what you are dealing with. But know....I am new at this and not an expert like so many of these members here.  I am just giving you a little background of what I have experienced so far because we have the same size tumor.

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2009 01:07PM jancie wrote: Piffken - I had the same regimen  4 A/C every two weeks and then 4 Taxol every 2 weeks.  I was prescribed Emend and Lorazepam for nausea and never once got nauseated.  I lost my hair on day 17.  Some foods started tasting awful about 5 weeks into treatment.  I got to where I only wanted to eat apples and oranges.  Even my most favorite food chocolate tasted "off".  I used Biotene toothpaste and mouthwash and you can get that at Target. The Taxol was the worse for me as I experienced excruciating joint pain to where they put me on morphine pills.  I did not get neuropathy but I was also taking gabapentin for shingles and I think that might have helped.  My nails turned brown and the whites of the nails increased towards the back of my nails but they never totally lifted off and I did have rippling in my nails. I was having a really hard time on Taxol so they did offer to put me on Taxotere but I refused as there is a thread here on the board of some women that have suffered permanent hair loss due to Taxotere and I didn't want to take the chance.  Yes, the chance of suffering permanent hair loss is a small percentage but because I had gotten almost all of the side effects of chemo that you could possibly get, I didn't want to be another statistic. I was pumped full of steroids to counteract any allergic reaction to the chemo and ended up gaining 20 lbs , also I because extremely bitchy while on steroids so I avoided my husband, friends, etc. It has been suggested by many of the gals that you get your dental work done first.  Go in for a check up and get any cavities filled, etc. before you start chemo because chemo is hard on your teeth.  I was able to get a dental appointment with a dentist within 4 days when I explained to him I was going to start chemo - normally I would have had to wait 30 days or longer since he was a new dentist.

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2011 05:10AM jancie wrote: Rider - I just noticed this thread in the active topics and pulled it up because of your user name   I don't respond normally to DCIS threads because I am not well versed with DCIS, however, if you go to the DCIS forum and look up Beesie's posts - she has invaluable information for you. On a personal note - my horse is what kept my sanity throughout all of my treatments.  It became difficult to ride because I have a very hot young horse who takes the energy out of you and I lost my ability to focus 100% because of chemo and then there was the fatigue factor. I did ride throughout my treatments because I needed that for my mental wellbeing.  Most days my lessons would last 20 minutes as that is all I could do so I had my trainer ride my horse for the first 30 minutes and then I got on her for the last half hour.  I didn't care if it was only 20 minutes - I needed to ride!   I guess what I am trying to say is keep riding if that is what makes you happy.  The treatments will go so much easier if you have something to look forward to. Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2010 04:48AM jancie wrote: When I was diagnosed I immediately was set up for a bone scan to make sure I didn't have bone mets and also for a chest x-ray.  I also had a breast MRI. 6 months after completing radiation I insisted on a petscan.  They don't like to do them right after radiation because you can get false positives.  Fortunately my scans cost me $100 each so I can afford to insist on really close monitoring. I had 2 MRI's on my hip this year along with 4 sets of x-rays and they still can't figure out where this pain is coming from.  I am beginning to believe the tamoxifen might have something to do with it. I had 3 sets of chest x-rays done this year when I broke my ribs.  The great news is that if something was not right - it would show up. This past month I have had 3 sets of x-rays to my left arm and shoulder due to another accident - thankfully only fractured bones showed up. From what I understand from the doctors, the insurance companies are putting pressure on them to not order so many scans.  Personally I would get a full scan once a year if I can because it takes the worry away from me that the cancer might come back and I wouldn't know about it for months and months.

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2011 11:03PM jancie wrote: I also chose lumpectomy and radiation.  My first gut feeling was cut those suckers off but after a couple of weeks and talking to the wonderful ladies here, I found out that lumpectomy and radiation gave me as good of a chance as having a masectomy.  I had a large area removed from my size B breasts and although I was expecting a smaller breast or a divet - I had neither.  I am 2 years out of treatment and the only thing you could see if you look really closely is that one nipple is at the most 1/4" higher than the other due to radiation - radiation shrinks your skin (for lack of a better term) - I still have some chemo fog issues so words don't always come to me easily. Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2010 11:45AM jancie wrote: I totally get about not wanting to have the ends trimmed even 1/16" because we work so hard to get it to grow back.  The main thing with Biotin is to take enough!  I don't buy the pills that are 1,000 mcg because then I would be taking 10 pills per night.  It comes in a 5,000 mcg bottle and so take 2 every night or every morning - whatever your normal pill routine is. Thanks for the compliment on Jazzy - that picture was taken about 3 years ago so she is much bigger now.  I was supposed to ride her today but we are having major storms in the valley and also in the mountains.  My trainer's clients pretty much cancelled on her today because of the storms and it wasn't feasible for her to go up and ride one horse when it is an hour drive to the barn.  I am only 1 of 2 clients that is at a facility with an indoor arena. Apple - thanks for sharing your personal viewpoint.  Are you ok with not having reconstruction? Shockedat39 - nice to hear from you again!!  Great to hear that your bone scan test came out clean also.  I was at the point that I was pretty much OK with having a bilateral but I wanted to know what I would look like and not be surprised which is why I viewed the pictures.  Had I not and woken up from surgery I think from a mental aspect I would have been devastated by the shock.  Your husband's response made me so very proud of him for supporting you the way that he did - you got one heck of a husband there!  Stay married! Beesie - It is because of YOUR response I am taking the treatment route that I am.  I asked myself and the oncologist if there was any benefit to having a mastectomy versus a lumpectomy if chemo was done first and he said "none".  Medically a mastectomy is not necessary at this time UNLESS chemo doesn't do the job that we are expecting.  I also found out today that they did the FISH test and I am HER2 NEGATIVE!!!  They couldn't tell for sure on the regular pathology testing because my numbers were too low so they proceeded to do the FISH test and those results took longer to get.  I am going to post on the IDC forum area the treatment that we have come up with to beat the crap out of my cancer and I will say this....I am so very pleased. LisaSDCA - I did do a search on Alloderm and if my treatment plan that is in place right now doesn't work, I will research it further.  Ailenroc - I read your thread days ago, the entire thing by the way, and was so thankful when I read it because you shared every aspect of your treatment and the outcome, etc.  I think that one thread is going to be helpful to us newbies for years to come.
Posts.Title: I am so confused as to which route to take jancie Beesie

Posts.Content: jancie wrote: My bone scan last week came out clean - good news! My MRI came out with 2 additional spots in left breast, one lymph node looked like it might be abnormal and two spots in my right breast that were undetected in the mammogram. So I totally psyched myself of having to probably go with bilateral mastectomy with reconstruction. Had a second ultrasound today of both breasts.  The spots that were showing up in the MRI were insignificant according to the doctor and he didn't do any more biopsys.  I wasted a valium! Then I went on a website that was posted in another forum that showed pictures of what women look like when they get mastectomys, the reconstruction process, the filler things (I am tired and can't remember the name right now) and then finally the reconstruction.  It showed pictures using the DIEP method and the method where they take muscle and tissue off your back, implants, etc. I so DON'T want a mastectomy after looking at those pictures. I know I can't do a DIEP reconstruction because my stomach is totally flat.  I have no fat on my back and so my only route is really implants.  But looking at those pictures - I saw so many reconstruction jobs that were not done well at all. I am now dreading my appointment with the cancer panel tomorrow.  They have already gotten together and reviewed all of my test results, etc. and they have set a game plan in place for me as far as treatment goes. I know my breast surgeon said that the only way I could do a lumptectomy and radiation was to have chemo done first since I have small boobs and a 4CM tumor.  Ok, I can deal with the chemo if I need to but I am so not prepared for a mastectomy after looking at all of those pictures. I know being prepared for what you are going to look like after surgery is the smart thing to do but now I wish I remained ignorant. I feel like a kid now reacting in this manner and not a mature adult.  I am ticked off with myself for not being more mature about this. I don't know what my recurrence rate for the cancer coming back.  I want to LIVE by all means and will do what is necessary but dammit - this SUCKS! Never Alone - My TaTa Sisters are always with me! Dx 12/30/2008, IDC, 4cm, Stage IIB, Grade 1, 0/5 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2011 09:23PM jancie wrote: Lago is correct.  Keep them on - do not remove them.  They will come off by themselves and if they don't then wait for the doctor to remove them. I had steri-strips on my breast after lumpectomy.  Even though I showered regularly they stayed on which is exactly what is supposed to happen.  12 days later I went to the doctor and he removed them.  They do keep the incision nice and tight and closed up - my stitches were on the inside of me (dissolvable ones) and so it was really important those strips stayed on as long as possible before my follow up appt. The itching - that is because your incision is healing.  It is like having a scab on your knee - when your skin starts to heal underneath the scab - the scab starts itching like crazy and you want to peel it off so badly knowing it will hurt.  Best to wait until the scab starts to peel off on the edges before you go yank it!

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2010 04:38PM jancie wrote: You will be under general anethesia for this procedure and won't know a thing. The surgery is not so bad - pretty quick. You will not be able to lay on that side at night for about 2 weeks because of tenderness. Depending on how much tissue they take out will depend on how much pain you are going to be in and also what kind of pain tolerance level you have.  I have an extremely low pain tolerance level.  I stayed on the pain meds.  About 3 weeks later I felt some "zinging" in the breast - not painful but it bothered me and it was the nerve endings trying to repair themselves. I am still tender where they did my lumpectomy but they took out a huge amount of tissue from me - I only feel tenderness if I push in that area but normal day to day activities and sleeping, etc. don't bother me in the least.

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2013 07:52PM jancie wrote: Annie - I didn't want to scare you last night when you posted so I didn't want to talk about malignancy, etc. I was diagnosed with a 4 cm tumor. I hadn't had a mammogram in 10 years which was really my fault and never did self breast exams. Mine probably grew for years and years as it was Grade 1 - slow growing. I had chemo first to reduce the size so I could have a lumpectomy. The odds were the same either masectomy or chemo and lumpectomy. Every choice you make is a personal choice to be made by YOU. Not your friends, not your husband -this is about YOU and what YOU want. Once the lab results are available after biopsy and you get the grade, HER2 status, ER/PR status - all of that is taken in consideration when your oncologist gives you a treatment plan. Like you, I was scheduled to meet a surgeon the same day I had a biopsy. The radiologist was 99% sure it was cancerous. I was just glad to have a surgeon consult set up immediately. This is a hard time but as you can see there are so many women/men here to support you and help you with any questions or concerns you might have. Take that ativan!!!! Just because your tumor was large does not necessarily mean it is dangerous. Ok, would love to have another word other than dangerous come to mind but I can't think of it right now. My brain is tired from work today.

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2010 09:29PM jancie wrote: I take 10,000 mcg of Biotin daily - have done this since May of 2009.  My hair is now 5 to 6" long.  My hair has always grown very slowly.  I now have a ton of hair on my head and the weight of the hair is allowing my curls to relax more that is until I get a hot flash and the curls start coming out. I am finding out that my hair is growing in spurts.  Seems like nothing happens and then overnight I have 1/8" to 1/4" of more hair.  I have also noticed this happens within a couple of days of my scalp being sore - I am thinking that my scalp is sore because the hair follicles are trying to push out so I always welcome those times I have a tender head because I know growth is coming! Moisterize the heck out of your hair - pay the extra money for those deep moisterizers that you leave on your head for 5 minutes.  Wash only every 2-3 days so that your natural oils from your scalp will moisterize your hair. In any case, those are my suggestions and they have worked for me!  I still take straight Biotin every single night and probably will until my hair gets down below my bra line again.

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2010 12:38AM jancie wrote: One-L - I lost my hair due to Adriamycin/Cytoxin  4 dense doses.  Lost it on day 16.  My hair started growing back just a little bit before I finished Taxol.  I did 4 dense doses of Taxol.  My chemo was once every 2 weeks.  It is a given when you do Adriamycin that you will lose your hair.  My hair started coming back from legs then upwards.  If only I had as much hair on my scalp as I did my legs I would have been happy.  My hair on my scalp came in last. I was traumatized by losing my hair.  I refused to look in a mirror.  Once it started growing back I was in front of the mirror at least 10  times a day checking for hair growth!  To me seeing a bald head on a daily basis was a constant reminder that I had cancer.  Before that, I could escape and not think about it.  With a bald head, the cancer was right there in front of my face 24/7 and I couldn't ignore it.

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2009 01:19AM jancie wrote: bbd - if you have LONG hair now - like down to your bra strap, it seems to help you get over the shock of losing all of your hair if you cut it short and wear it short for a little bit.  Going from long to bald is a shock.  I cut mine to a short bob for 2 weeks prior to starting chemo so I could handle losing my hair a little bit better - not that it helped that much. Marybe - Yes, I had Jose Heber do my hair one time.  He has a shop in Hollywood (LA), but he also goes to a shop in Dallas, Texas about 3 x per year and you have to book your appointment at least 6 months in advance to get in there.  He determines the color and the style and then has the stylists do your hair as he watches over them, he reviews what they have done and has them make adjustments, etc.  I told him I didn't want any color because (1) I didn't want to spend the money and (2) I had natural blonde hair.  Between the consultation fee and the haircut - the cost was around $230.  Mind you that was back in 1992.  I am sure the cost has risen quite a bit since then.  I LOVED what he did, the style was absolutely perfect for my face, age, etc. it was just too much work as I had to blow dry sections of my hair with a large roller brush to get it looking like he did it so I just let my hair grow out. Chelev - I WANT YOUR BANGS!!! BTW - A horse buddy of mine gave me a christmas gift last year of a soap product that exfoliates the skin.  A light bulb went off last week - what if I used that soap on my face to get rid of the peach fuzz growing on my cheeks from chemo?  Remember, I was the one that was too scared to shave.  I have used this product 5x now when I shower - just on my face and I scrub my face really good and the peach fuzz in finally disappearing.  It is not all gone but I would have to say 50% of it is gone!   If you want to try it - I found it online at www.bodycompletenow.com       You click on Skincare and it is called Sugar Creme Skin Smoother - size is 13.4 oz and it costs $13.95.  You could probably buy it in a local bath soap shop - I don't know.   She gave me the orange ginger smell one and it does smell good and it does make your skin feel smooth when you use it.  Oh and as little as I use this stuff will last me 3 years. Question - the top of my scalp is very tender.  I have a ton of hair (not long - just lots of it) so is the tenderness from the hair trying to grow or what?  The only time before I felt my scalp feeling tender was right before my hair started falling out from chemo.  This has been an on-going issue for weeks but kept forgetting to ask the question.

It is scary when the chemo nurses come out with these super thick gloves as they are handling it and you wonder "Hmmmmm....they are scared to get it on their skin yet they are infusing my blood with it?" I am not a water drinker at all.  Yes.....you should drink tons of water.  I tend to drink juice instead and used baby wipes for the first couple of days in lieu of toilet paper. My taste buds didn't go away until my 3rd treatment.  At that time the only thing that tasted good to me was oranges and I ate a ton of them.  Everything else tasted like cardboard - no taste at all. I was an awful cook during this treatment since I couldn't taste anything I tended to over spice all of the food I made.   In fact the only foods that tasted good were mexican and indian food at the time. I got through the red devil "ok"  not great - but it wasn't horrible.  I had more of a problem with Taxol and the severe joint pain associated with it.

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2009 02:16PM jancie wrote: Diane - I am 5 months PFC.  My hair came in white but changed color within 4 weeks to a mousy brown.  I started taking biotin 4 weeks before I finished chemo after talking to my oncologist who said biotin would not interfere with Taxol.  I think you should go on the advice of your oncologist as each one seems to have a different opinion.  I am taking 10,000 mcg of biotin nightly.  Those are the pills that I NEVER forget to take CCBaby - can't wait for my hair cut appointment on November 2nd!!!  I have followed your advice very closely.  I would be in that chair this week if my hairdresser was in town but I will just have a little bit more for her to work with.  She did say that she could "frost" my hair using a frosting cap or she might even be able to use foil but I don't think I have enough for her to do that. Quick question - because I have only ever highlighted my hair 3x in the past with red highlites - I can't remember if they do that when your hair is dry or they wash it first.  I don't want to put any mousse in my hair that day if she is going to do the dying when it is dry.  I figured I could save her a step and wash it at home before I go but then again if she has to wash it first, I like being pampered.  It always seems to feel better when someone else washes your hair.

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2010 03:51AM jancie wrote: I have read comments on several pages now about shaving off the initial white chemo hair - I am sorry for not addressing anyone in particular but I am overwhelmed right now with things going on in my life. My hair came in white at first just like some of ya'lls did also.  I didn't shave off the white chemo hair.  Within 1 month after that, my hair started coming in a mousy brown/gray color and you couldn't really see the white at all.  In fact the first trim I got 3 months PFC, even the ends were no longer white.  I can't explain it - that is just what happened. I guess what I am saying is maybe not be in such a hurry to do a second shave.  We endure enough losing our hair the first time around, I can't imagine shaving what little hair I had growing even though it was white and a totally different texture.  Heck, CCBaby will remember way back when it was mentioned to do scalp massages to promote hair growth and I told her NO WAY AM I MASSAGING MY SCALP - I didn't want to lose not one single strand of hair!!! I did wait 6 months before I started "frosting" my hair.  I wanted the chemo poison to be totally out of my system.  The lady at the wig shop encouraged me to wait because when you still have chemo in your system then you stand a chance of the color coming out "brassy" like CCBaby mentioned earlier.  You need your hairdresser to understand your new chemo hair.   I was a natural blonde so I frosted my hair twice 4 weeks apart with the old fashioned frosting cap.  This was less damaging to my hair than to totally dye 100% of it.  After the 3rd frosting, I love my hair color now!    Years ago I dyed my hair a strawberry blonde and I remember my scalp burning so bad.  I am hesitant to go that route again.  I would rather color the tips and leave the roots alone for now.

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2010 02:06AM jancie wrote: MAGOB - I had a problem with my hair sticking straight up in the back at the crown of my head.  I found many of the mousses and styling gels to be too sticky and just didn't like the way it left my hair feeling.  Felt like I had sprayed on an entire can of hair spray.  I went to Walgrens and got a product called Special Effects Molding Wax.  It comes in a green jar with a silver top and is around $4. I went through one jar of that in about 2 months so I thought I would try a Pantene molding wax product - again that sticky feeling that I didn't like. The Special Effects product leaves your hair feeling soft as though you have nothing in it - you just have to put it on lightly by applying it to your finger tips and quickly rubbing your fingers through your hair so that you get even coverage - kind of wisk your finger tips through your hair.

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2010 09:06PM jancie wrote: one-L - I am no expert on the chemos but I do know (in layman terms) that Taxotere and Taxol are like sister drugs.  With Taxol I believe you have a higher chance of neuropathy and joint pain.  I know my oncologist suggested that I switch to Taxotere since my joint pain was so severe but I already knew about the potential of permanent hair loss so I decided to stick with the Taxol. When you are doing TCH - I don't know if you have a choice of Taxotere or Taxol.  I don't know if Taxol works with Carboplatin (spelling?) and Herceptin.   I just googled chemo drugs (sorry cut and paste doesn't work with my Mozilla) but the website www.tirgan.com has a list of all of the chemo drugs and side effects. Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2010 02:41PM jancie wrote: Jaimieh - I think you and I are pretty much on the same page for hair growth.  Mine came in wavy and a little bit on the curly side but not what they consider chemo curls.  I use a medium size roller brush when I blow dry my hair.  It doesn't straighten it out all of the way as I hate to use too much heat on my hair but it does make it look great.  I asked my hairdresser about using a flat iron and she said "No!, not yet.....there is too much heat in the flat irons and you will damage your hair" She might have said that to me because (1) I am frosting it every 8 weeks which is pretty much like bleaching it versus coloring it - so more chemicals on the hair and (2) my hair is baby soft and in great shape right now. I didn't realize how good my hair could look blowing it dry with a roller brush in sections.  Maybe you can schedule a hair appointment and ask them to dry/style it this way and see how it comes out.  If I lived near you I would be there in a heartbeat to show you how to do it. It is hard doing the back of my head - I can't see what I am doing at all so I have to stop and get the mirror out and make adjustments on some of the sections but I am getting better at it each time.  Right now I am thrilled that I have a cute short haircut.  I also use a product made by FX Special Effects - molding wax.  I put a little bit on the tips of my fingers and rub it lightly on the top of my hair as you don't want to get a glob of it anywhere, then put a little bit more on my finger tips and go for another section.  Then I can start pulling and shaping my hair the way I want to and the great thing about this stuff is that  your hair never feels sticky, waxy, pasty, or how it feels if you put hairspray on it.  Your hair feels totally natural.  I have tried other products and have given them away but this stuff - dang it is good.  I got mine at Walgrens for $4 and I am still on the first can (I can't think of a better word) - but long story short, one small container lasts me 3 months or longer.

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2009 11:22PM jancie wrote: Stef58 - one thing that might soften your hair is to wash it the first time with dawn dishsoap.  No kidding - I am not joking.  The 2nd wash - with the shampoo of your preference and the lastly condition.  I am not conditioning my hair since I only have 1/2 to 1" in most places. Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2009 03:35PM jancie wrote: Ladies - I want to share with you a very touching story about what happened to me today regarding my wigs as this story truly shows how generous strangers can be. I had been trying to find a rack with pegs that you would hang baseball type hats on that mounted on a wall with round pegs on the end for the purpose of hanging up my wigs.  I have 3 cats and the last thing I needed was to put them on wig stands and have my cats nest in them. I went to Target and couldn't find anything so I headed to Home Depot.  I found an older gentleman (around 60" - grandfather type man) and asked him for assistance.  He showed me a shelf with dowels but the dowels were straight and I was worried about damage to the interior of the wig so I asked him if they had different dowels I could change out. We went over to that section of the store and they didn't have anything.  I FINALLY told him that I was starting chemo next week and I needed something to hang my wigs so I needed something round on the end.  So he took me to kitchen cabinet hardware and showed me a "round pull" and I said that would be excellent. He then started asking me if I needed anything fancy, how many wigs, how far apart the spacing, etc. He started writing all of this down.  He then said "go eat breakfast and come back in an hour" I looked at him and said "are you saying that you are going to make this for me?"  He said "yes" I started bawling like a baby because I just could not believe this man was going to go out of his way and have this made for me. I gave him a huge hug and said thanks. I came back an hour later with my stepson and he showed me what they had made and it was PERFECT.  I then started crying again because of his compassion and generousity.  He then said the store manager wanted to meet me so I met him and started crying even harder thanking him for going way above and beyond, etc. They wouldn't even let me pay for it - they took an hour of their time, their materials and gave it to me free. I can tell you this.....I have shopped Home Depot for years but from now on I will not be shopping at Lowes - I am giving all of my business to Home Depot. There are truly wonderful people that you meet in this world that are kind and compassionate.

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2011 11:58PM jancie wrote: I haven't been on this thread for 32 pages.  Jen1832 - PFC - Post *$&%^ Chemo is what it stands for Bdavis - I was a natural blonde.  My hair came in a mousy brownish gray color.  I waited 6 months before I went to a professional as (1) I wanted my hair to grow in healthy without chemical treatment and (2) I was also worried about how the chemo hair would color and didn't want it turning orange on me.  We used a frosting cap for the first 3 colors treatments.  This way she would put in two colors - base color plus highlights.  The next treatments were basically highlights in different blonde shades so my hair looked naturally blonde.  I would suggest someone that has been doing hair for 20 years or so and not an amatuer out of school even though it does cost more.  My hair finally got long enough to where I could foil it. I haven't put any color in for 4 months now as I am giving my hair a rest over the summer.  I was so hoping that the sun would naturally bleach it as it has in the past but I guess I am not in the sun as much as before because it isn't doing anything for my hair. As far as counting how many weeks you are - you start with the last day of treatment.  At least that is what most everyone has done in the past.  I finished chemo the end of May 2008 and my hair is past my shoulders by about 3".  Keep in mind I have gotten baby trims every 8 weeks so it would be a couple of inches longer if I never trimmed it.

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2009 09:05PM jancie wrote: Oh my gosh - I am overwhelmed and crying happy tears because of all of the support of the women that have gone through this helping so many of us newbies!  I saw the general surgeon yesterday and did not get the news I wanted to hear - but then who does? Since I really don't want a masectomy he said I would have to do chemo firs to try to shrink the tumor to where it wouldn't be so disfiguring to do a lumpectomy. Ok, this I can understand but that doesn't mean I wanted to hear this. He suggested that I go in front of the cancer review board next Thursday and get an opinion from them before making any decisions.  I will meet one on one with an oncologist, pathologist, emphedema specialist, general surgeon, plastic surgeon, etc. He also scheduled an MRI and bone scan.  I am having those done tomorrow. I asked for pain meds and valium and he said that he wanted me to go to my general practioner for those.  Of course I called that doctor immediately and was able to see him today. He gave me a prescription for 180 valium and 20 Lortab.  YIPPPEEEEE.  I am going to take a valium before I get my MRI and bone scan test done.  I need something to take the edge off since I am having anxiety attacks over this crap! My regular doctor also told me that WHATEVER the cancer review board recommended is what I need to follow even it that means chemo, masectomy, radiation and then reconstruction. So my question if any of you are on tonight is why can't they just do masectomy's on both breasts and immediate reconstruction.  A friend of mine that got breast cancer back in 1984 did this and her cancer hasn't come back.  Unfortunately I have been out of touch with her since I moved to Utah and have no means of reaching her now to ask her. I guess it all depends on what kind of cancer and how far it has spread?  She didn't know she had cancer until she noticed discharge coming out of her nipples which means to me that it had to have been pretty advanced? I so wish I didn't have to wait until next Thursday to speak to the cancer panel.  This waiting and pre-testing is so hard.  I just want a game plan established and get a move on with this horrible thing invading my body. I have resigned myself to the fact that I might lose my boobs and I might lose my hair.  If that is the case then I had better in the least get some bigger and better boobs out of the deal!  If not, then where is the silver lining other than the fact that I get to keep on living? Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2009 01:57PM jancie wrote: I am new here also so I don't have any advice right now but wanted to welcome you to the group. Is there a breast care center close to where you live?  There is one about 10 minutes from my house and I was able to get so much information from the people that work there and they have set me up with a panel of breast cancer experts to talk to one on one at no charge to me at all. What limited information I do know is that you really need to be able to read and understand your pathology report.  There is a wealth of information here that explains about the hormone receptors and what it means to be positive or negative.  It is good news if you are estrogen positive but bad news if you are HER2 positive.  I never even heard of those terms until I got a copy of my pathology report and started doing some research here in all of the different forums. Sorry that you had to join us but I am finding this to be one heck of a group of women and I like them lots!

Now that I am out of treatment, I just call and ask for an appointment with my oncologist every 3 months.  After June (18 months since diagnosis), I will only be seeing my oncologist every 6 months UNLESS there is a problem.  I mentioned to my oncologist yesterday about not wanting to wait 6 months to see him as he is really reassuring to me emotionally.  He told me that I could make an appointment with him any time, as many times as I want to - he would be there for me. Like you, I didn't feel comfortable with the PA.  I didn't feel as though I was getting the quality of care like seeing my oncologist. I would suggest instead of just asking for an appointment - call and tell them "I need an appointment with Dr. X"

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2010 02:55AM jancie wrote: Lovelyface - sorry you had such a horrible experience with your surgeon.  My surgeon took out a chunk of my breast - every bit of tissue where the tumor originally was plus the clear margins.  However, he sewed the tissue together in the inside of my breast.  You would think I would have this huge dimple in my breast and I even questioned him why my breast looked so normal considering how much he removed and he said it was the way he sewed me up.  If you couldn't see my scar (although small) you would never be able to tell I had breast surgery. The surgeon was a "general surgeon" but he specializes in breast surgery.  I don't NEED any reconstruction but I am going to go ahead and get my breasts lifted just because I can and they tend to droop when you are 50 years old.   If you have any questions when you start chemo - let me know.  I am more than happy to help you.   Funny story though - everyone kept telling me DRINK WATER DRINK WATER DRINK WATER to flush out the chemo.  I hate drinking water.  My thought was "if I flush out the chemo then I am not leaving it in my body long enough to work - I want that chemo working"  Ok, wrong response but it didn't harm me to not drink water.   Yes, it is better to drink water and keep hydrated.  Just wish I could tolerate the stuff.  I figure coffee is nothing more than flavored water.  I know the caffeine does dehydrate your body but I can't live without my coffee.

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2010 03:19PM jancie wrote: I did 16 weeks of chemo - 4 treatments 2 weeks apart of Adriamycin/Cytoxin and then 4 treatments 2 weeks apart of Taxol so it was 16 weeks all together.  I did chemo prior to surgery and then rads.  Normally the doctors will have you wait 3-4 weeks between the various types of treatments so that your body can heal up.  So I had a 4 week break between chemo and surgery and then another 4 week break between surgery and radiation. One of the standard protocols for radiation is to go 5 weeks Mon-Friday and then the 6th week they do a booster radiation for 5 days.  30 treatments in all of rads.  Rads was probably the easiest for me as far as SE but I got so darn fatigued by the rads - each week it was more and more difficult for me to get anything done.  The last 3 weeks of rads I was sleeping at least 14 hours a day.  Not everyone gets the fatigue to the point I did but do know you will get tired and it is cummulative - in other words the fatigue gets worse as you go along.  I would have to say from reading here for the past 1.5 years is that the standard for rads is 25 to 30 treatments.

Posts.Content: jancie wrote: Last Tuesday (December 30th) I was diagnosed with breast cancer.  I was so shocked that I forgot to ask questions as to what kind, etc. I have made several phone calls since then to the breast care center and found out the following: I have IDC, low grade, estrogen receptors positive, HER2+, and the size is 3.2 x 3.6 x 1.5. I don't know if there is lymph node involvement until I have surgery.  I meet with the surgeon tomorrow to discuss my treatment options. I have small breasts (between A and B cup).  I am 48 years old, physically fit and when I say physically fit I can run circles around the 20 year olds.  My initial thought was to "cut the darn thing out" but I am leaning now towards a less invasive type of treatment such as lumpectomy and radiation if that is an option. One day I am fine and the next day I can't stop crying.  I know that treatment options have come so far in the last 20 years.  I just never thought that I would have to deal with this personally. I am so very scared.  Never Alone - My TaTa Sisters are always with me! Dx 12/30/2008, IDC, 4cm, Stage IIB, Grade 1, 0/5 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2011 04:54AM jancie wrote: I burned but not the point of blistering.  I had bought some aloe vera gel from a health store.  The stuff you buy at Target, etc. has alcohol in it so you want PURE aloe vera gel and yes....it looks gross because it is brown in color but that helped me from blistering. Posts.Title: "Easy" part of treatment? MY A**! BlueCowgirl Tazzy

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2009 10:06PM - edited Jan 11, 2009 10:08PM by jancie You ladies are awesome! My MRI results were not good.  They found 2 areas of "enhancement" in my left breast where my tumor is that they did not see in the ultrasound.  They also found 2 areas in my right breast.  There is one lymph node that might be abnormal. I was immediately scheduled for another ultrasound on both breasts and more biopsys.  Having endured this procedure once already and the pain associated with it you can imagine the anxiety I am feeling right now.  I am having this procedure done on Tuesday so the results should be available to the cancer board on Thursday. I am shocked that I have not become a total basket case.  I guess I have come to terms and acceptance that this is what I have to deal with.  I have emotionally accepted the fact that I am going to lose my hair and my boobs.  However, I know that when the time actually comes I probably will be in a totally different mindset.  It is like death - even though you know it is going to happen, when it actually happens that fact that you knew about it and expected it doesn't make the event any easier to deal with. I have never questioned "why me" because I have looked at it more from the angle of "why NOT me?"  I am no different than any other woman, I am not special and chit just happens. My general surgeon made a statement that had a huge impact which was "you need to be concerned about living because that is our goal - for you to LIVE".  He said that when I lost it when he mentioned that I more than likely would have to go through chemo. I want to LIVE.  I will do whatever surgical and drug methods I need to do in order to survive this.  I can't thank ya'll enough for the emotional support that you have provided me.  I love the fact that all of you share your personal experiences based on your own personal thoughts. I don't think I could handle it if all I read was responses that said 'CUT IT OUT, CUT IT OUT"  I think you know what I mean.  ALL of you realize that everyone's decision is their own to make and you don't try to persuade any of us to make a certain decision based on your own decision and how you felt when you found out that you had cancer.  I think this is what makes this board and the people here very special.  Instead of browbeating us newbies to make certain decisions that you would personally make yourself,  instead you help provide us with the necessary information that we need to make our OWN decision. Hugs to all of you!

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2011 12:28AM jancie wrote: Kate - my tumor was 4 cm the size of a ping pong ball.  I had the SNB done first and I have a very low tolerance for pain so yes....I took pain meds but like I said I have a very low tolerance for pain - I am a total wuss to say the least.  Then I did chemo to shrink my tumor because I wanted a lumpectomy.  My BS still took out as much tissue and more of what my tumor originally was and I was a B cup size.  You can't even tell I had surgery other than a small scar that you have to look for.  I have no dimpling or divet or anything else.  The radiation I had after surgery caused one nipple to be slightly higher than the other but most people wouldn't even notice. I was able to totally function a week after my lumpectomy but then again most people can function 2-3 days later - I am a wuss like I stated above. I had no lymph node involvement even though my tumor was fairly large before it was detected as I never did self breast exams nor had I been to a doctor in over 10 years.  Because I was Grade 1 - my tumor grew very slowly.  However due to the size - my stage ended up being a IIA. The staging is done based on lymph node involvement and size of tumor.  In your case where IDC and DCIS is involved, the staging will be based on the size of the IDC tumor - irregardless of what size the DCIS area is.  At least that is what I have always understood and I am sure if I am wrong someone will come right behind me and correct me.  Take a deep breath - there are wonderful ladies here that will always have your back!

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2009 12:32AM jancie wrote: Carlag67 - Thanks for the wonderful advice! My husband is going with me for the ultrasound on Tuesday and also on Thursday when I speak to the cancer panel.  I asked him to come because I would forget half of what they tell me and also he is GREAT at remembering and taking notes. A funny but sad story, my mare had colic surgery years ago and my husband went with me to the vets to check on her.  The vet came out to talk to me and I was hysterical, crying, etc. because she meant so much to me and the chances of her surviving this surgery was only 50/50.  The vet took one look at me and then started talking to my husband about the procedures, recovery, etc.  My husband knows NOTHING about horses but the vet knew immediately that I wasn't going to retain one word that he said to me when I was so upset.  My dear husband repeated word for word exactly what the vet had said the next day when I had calmed down.  I still laugh when I think about it because here is my husband asking the vet intelligent questions and yet knows nothing at all about horses or colic but somehow he knew what questions he should ask. I am glad that your Aunt got you moving in the right direction!  You have kids to think about and she was making sure you remembered what is important in your life and what you have to live for. I have a wonderful husband and a beautiful filly to live for.  My mare ended up dying but I do have her filly that means the world to me and I couldn't have my filly suffer the loss of her mom and me both. The valium is taking the edge off when needed and I am sleeping well at night.  I need to remain as physically strong as possible and get plenty of rest prior to starting my journey of surgery, chemo, etc. I know I will feel so much better emotionally once I find out if this cancer has progressed past my breasts into other areas of the body.  I just need to know - hard to explain but I like having a very structured type life so knowing all of the facts are important to me. thanks for everything!

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2009 04:59PM jancie wrote: I don't know how anybody could have gone through BC without the internet and most of all the online forums where we can talk to one another through our fears and concerns about our surgeries, post operative experiences, etc. Just joining this group has helped me tremendously.  I can't thank each one of you enough for your support and your personal stories of what you have been through.  It is encouraging to hear from all the newbies - and I expect that I will gain so many friends through this site. I am very fortunate to be dealing with a breast care center and not doing this individually.  The breast care center gave me a 3" 3-ring binder full of information with questions to ask the surgeon, the oncologists, etc.  I have the option of talking to the breast cancer panel which includes specialists in oncology, plastic surgery, RN's, and lympedema experts.  There is a special clinic just for lymphedema on how to try to prevent this side effect, what exercises to do, etc.  They are also putting me in touch with a local BC support group that meets at the hospital weekly.  I have an assigned RN who is a clinical coordinator of breast care cancer services.  She is my go-to person on all questions day or night. I have looked at the information provided on reconstruction.  I don't think any type of Tram Flap, or buttock flap will be an option due to (1) I have been smoking for 20 years - 1/2 pack a day and (2) I don't have anything extra available to take out.  Being very lean isn't a lot of help right now. What amazes me is the fact that I feel so healthy.  I haven't felt this way in so many years until about 1 year ago when I started working at a horse barn 8 hours a day doing manual labor.  In one day I typically lift approximately 2,000 lbs over the course of 8 hours.  I had lost the 30 lbs I had gained over the last 10 years and am back to a size 4.  I haven't been sick nor been to a doctor in about 8 years other than for horse related injuries. I am determined to take this one step at a time, one day at a time.  Yes, I am scared but I am going to find a way to muster the strength to get through this and I  know I can do this with ya'lls help. Thanks again!  I will update tomorrow after my appointment with the general surgeon.

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2011 01:39AM jancie wrote: Leighsa - your emotions possibly might be all over the place and that is OK! As women we feel like we have to be strong and in most cases we are - we seem to put up a brave front to others when we are really scared to death. I remember when I was first dx'd.  I went from anger, sad, crying, numb, back to anger, sad, crying, numbness and the cycle went on and on. Once I got into treatment I felt better because I knew then that I was killing the cancer - I had a plan and we all like to have plans! At the end of my treatment I felt a huge letdown however, I was expecting this from talking to other women.  You go through months of killing the cancer, treatment is over and now what are we supposed to do?  The last year was filled with doctor appointments, seeing our oncologists, radiologists, breast surgeons, chemo, radiation, surgeries, etc. and then it all stops except for Tamoxifen or an AI.  But life does go on and we learn to live with it.  For some people it takes longer than others. Whatever you do, don't beat yourself up.  You are allowed your emotions, your pity parties, your crying spells or whatever.

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2009 06:12PM jancie wrote: Wishewere - I got a prescription from my PCP for Chantrix the week I found out I had BC.  However, I did not take it until I talked to my oncologist because I didn't want any chemo treatment delayed due to the fact I had Chantrix in my system.  My oncologist who is very respected and works at the Huntman's Cancer Institute here in Salt Lake City, Utah told me to start taking the Chantrix immediately and that it would not have any effect at all on the chemo treatment. The chemo I am taking is Adriamycin and Cytoxin followed by Taxol.  I totally trust my oncologist and he was highly recommended to me by so many people. Yes, there are many of us that smoke and nothing ticks me off more than to have a doctor refuse to provide a service because we smoke.  I have had numerous operations in the past and it did not delay my healing process one iota.  I do agree that smoking will restrict the blood vessels for certain types of reconstruction surgery which is why if I were going to have a masectomy I would have chosen implants for that reason and also the fact that I am too thin to take fat from anywhere else in my body and besides to me it would be a less invasive way to recreate boobs versus cutting another part of your body but that is my own personal opinion and there are upsides and downsides to all of the reconstruction options out there, again it is all a matter of your own personal choice and what feels best for YOU.

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2015 12:23PM jancie wrote: I am 5 years out of treatment and have severe chronic pain. The first couple of years it was mainly in my hips. When I am having a rough day the pain migrates from my hips to my knees and then down my shins so my entire lower body hurts bad. I am still on Tamoxifen and likely will be for another 4 years as my oncologist wants me on it for 10 years. At this point I don't think going off Tamoxifen is going to give me any relief whatsoever. I now work as a mail carrier so come rain or shine I am delivering mail and that includes lots of snowy days (although not much snow in Utah this year). I take 2 percocet each morning when I start work and 2 at night but mind you I am taking (2) 10/325 which is a hefty dose. I tend to hurt less when I am active. The 2 days a week I don't work I hurt so much more because I am not moving as much. Using a heating pad at night when my knees and shins are killing me tends to help - at least it soothes the pain somewhat so I can sleep. Working is the only thing that keeps me going. I still have tendencies to go into a deep depression due to the pain where all I want to do is stay in bed for days on end. My job doesn't allow me to do this and I think it is probably saved my sanity because I am forced to get out of bed in the mornings. You don't get the luxury of calling in "sick" when you deliver mail for a living. I wish there was an answer to this chronic pain but it is a condition that I am learning to live with albeit very difficult at times.

Posts.Content: May 23, 2012 11:13PM jancie wrote: My hair fell out on Day 15.  I had dose dense chemo so I went every other week for 8 sessions total.  Basically it took me four months as I went twice a month. SE's - everyone is different.  I did get shingles so if you can - you might want to ask for the vaccine.  They won't give it to you once you start chemo. Go to the dentist before chemo. I did ok on adriamycin - lost my sense of taste which only ticked me off when chocolate started tasting bad. On taxol - had pretty major joint pain but did not get neuropathy.  My nails did not fall off - did lift a little bit off the nail beds but never fell off.  You just don't know ahead of time what kind of SE's you are going to get. I didn't get the port and looking back I wish I had.  My veins are destroyed from chemo which doesn't sound bad until you end up in the ER and have 9 bruises up and down your arms because they can't hit a vein. My hair started growing back while I was on Taxol.  It never grows back fast enough.  By 6 months I had enough hair to get a baby trim to get rid of the scraggley ends - my hair didn't even look as good as a pixie cut but now it is down to my bra line and I am happy. I was vain - I only went out in public in wigs.  I bought 7 of them so I could have fun with them.  All different colors and styles so each day it was "ok, who do I want to look like today?"  I was also fortunate that I had enough hair that I could ditch my wigs in summer when it got too hot. The one thing that surprised me was the lack of nose hairs and what that does.  You nose just drips all of the time as there is nothing there to catch the drips so you need to keep kleenex or a hanky on hand. I might think of more later but I am tired right now.

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2009 12:55PM jancie wrote: Luv2sing - I am a little bit perplexed why the doctor would open her mouth and tell you it was cancer before a biopsy was done because most doctors wouldn't dream of doing that.  However, these doctors have seen these cancerous lumps so many times that they so often know it is cancer before the biopsy is even done.  The doctor that did my ultrasound within 5 minutes of seeing the pictures of my mammogram knew that I had cancer and he took 3 biopsys right then and there.  I could look in his eyes and know what he was thinking but he wouldn't say it.  He really didn't have to tell me, I could see the look in his eyes and his concern for me. I am glad that you caught it early and can do a lumpectomy.  Is your doctor going to order additional tests such as a bone scan, lymph node biopsy, etc?  It is important to your final treatment plan to know if the cancer has spread at all.  I was fortunate that my cancer is contained within my breast but am still going through chemo to try to reduce the size of the tumor so that hopefully I can get a lumpectomy. Valium has become my new best friend!  Unfortunately I can't type worth a crap when it is still in my system and have to keep backspacking every other word.  My doctor gave me a prescription for 10 mg Valium - I would not even attempt to drive on it - so be very cautious.   It makes me quite loopy and so very relaxed

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2009 02:21AM jancie wrote: I was fortunate to have my diagnostic mammogram, ultrasound and biopys all on the same day, however it was on a Friday and the lab takes 24 to 48 hours.  The time wouldn't start ticking until Monday morning and I did get my results Tuesday afternoon. That weekend before I got my results I was a total basketcase!  I was on this site reading everything I possibly could.  I knew in my heart that I had cancer - it was a gut feeling I had so I was not so shocked when I heard from the radiologist. I agree the waiting is a nightmare.  Then once you get your DX - you have to wait and see how you are going to be treated - it goes on and on.  On top of that there is a waiting period between treatments - you could be doing surgery first then wait 3 weeks to do chemo or radiation depending on what your treatment is. I have 4 periods of treatment in which I have to wait 3 weeks between the different types of treatment.  It is during this time I feel like I am sitting here not doing anything at all to battle my cancer and it drives me crazy.  But your body has to heal in between all of this. Let us know what your results are.  You will find a wealth of support and information at this site.

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2011 02:44PM jancie wrote: Granny - as time goes on you will find a new normal life.  You have just finished treatments and sometimes there is a small let down - when we are in treatment we know we are actively killing the cancer.  Once treatments stops we think "geez...no longer actively killing it so is it going to come back?" I finished my treatments Sept 2009.  I am in a new place now with my life.  Yes, the nagging thoughts of reoccurence sets in here and there but not on a daily basis.  I still have major anxiety issues related to the cancer and scans and other things that never gave me anxiety attacks before.  I know I will never be the same person again but I am getting to a place where I am finding peace within myself but it took a LONG TIME for that to come. I lost all of 2009 due to treatments.  2010 wasn't much better because I was dealing with 7 fractures (2 different accidents).  I am hoping 2011 is going to be better.  I just had a follow up mammogram - yes it was very upsetting.  The orders from the doctor was to get a diagnostic mammo on the right breast (my cancer was on the left side) and an ultrasound on the left breast as I still have swelling in my left arm from breaking it in 3 places.  Well I go in and they will only do a screening on the right breast!  Now they are telling me to get back ASAP for a left breast mammo.  I meet with my orthopedic surgeon next week and I will see if he recommends I do that now or wait longer.  A year ago I would have been in a total panic.  I will say that when I went for my mammo I went into a full blown anxiety attack.  I have been told that as years go by, it does get better.

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2009 12:28AM jancie wrote: I have only done 5 rads so far and I am already fatigued.  Don't really know if it is all due to radiation treatments or me just being stressed out but today I pretty much stayed in bed. I asked my radiologist about the 3 weeks versus 6 weeks rads and how do they compute who gets what treatment.  I was curious because the chemo killed my tumor (shrunk it down to nothing) and I had no lymph node involvement. The doctor told me that some radiologists will do the complete radiation in 3 weeks but they will give you a stronger dosage so in essence, you get the same amount of radiation in less time but according to her (doctor) she preferred to do the radiation over 6 weeks as it was less damaging to the skin.  I will get 5 weeks of whole breast radiation and the last week will be booster radiation where they radiate a certain area of my breast only. I was also told that they will continue to weigh me weekly as most breasts do get larger when you gain weight and they want to make sure they are still pinpointing the correct area.  This is also one  reason they are doing weekly x-rays if I understood her correctly.   The doctor wants to make sure that she is hitting the target area and it is a doublecheck feature. My nipple is already tender but I was told that was to be expected as the nipple is extremely sensitive.  I guess no different than when I would lay out in the sun without a top on - but I always made sure I put plenty of sunscreen on my nipples. I am having such a hard time getting up in the mornings since I started radiation and I have only completed one week so far.  I can only imagine how I am going to feel by week 3.

Posts.Content: May 26, 2012 11:49PM jancie wrote: Pam - everyone has different SE's from chemo.  There are great nausea drugs such as Emend and many women never get nauseated. However, depending on your chemo they may give you benedryl which will make you very sleepy. I know it is hard to ask for help - but DO ASK FOR HELP!  If someone volunteers to help you - take them up on it! For me that was also difficult as I prided myself on being superwoman - working 9 hours a day, keeping my house clean, grocery shopping, raising two stepchildren, etc.  I was so very independent. I had to become humble and realize that I could no longer do it all myself and days when I felt like crap - my dh had to grocery shop, cook, or bring something hope for us.  I had to learn to depend on him which was very difficult for me as I never wanted to ever be dependent on a man. After about 1 month - I sucked it up and took all of the help I could get and was very thankful to have friends that would bring me meals twice a week for 4 months while I was doing chemo. You don't know how you are going to feel anymore than the doctor really knows how your system is going to react so at least for the first appointment - have a friend drive you and stay there with you and if it were me I would also make arrangements to have your children picked up if your dh can't do so. I managed to get myself to and from the hospital for my infusions but not everyone can.  I did have my dh go with me the first time and if he wasn't available I sure would have had a friend go with me.  I didn't quite know what to expect and I needed a support system.

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2011 11:37PM jancie wrote: Unfortunately I gained 10 lbs after I heard the "news".  I guess my dh went and bought me way too much chocolate! I had chemo, lumpectomy and then radiation.  My knee jerk reaction when dx'd was to "cut them off - both of them" but when I learned that my survival rate was the same lumpectomy/radiation versus masectomy - I decided for myself that I wanted a less invasive surgery.  I am happy with my decision and have no regrets 2 years later. Some women don't have the option of rads because it is daily for 5-6 weeks and they might live too far away from a major hospital so their choice is going to be masectomy.  Sounds like you have a choice which is great. My tumor was 4 cm to start (size of a ping pong ball) and by the time I went into surgery the breast surgeon couldn't even feel it.  I did have a sentinal lymph node biopsy done prior to starting chemo as that was the only way we could tell if the cancer went into the lymph nodes.  Once you do chemo - it can hide those results.  The good thing about doing chemo ahead of the lumpectomy is that I found out for me that my body really responds well to chemo. Anxiety issues???  Ask for ativan, lorazepam, diazepam (valium) and also some sleep medication.  I take ambien nightly and lorazepam as needed for anxiety attacks.  Never could get the doctor to prescribe ambien, etc. until I got cancer and then they had no problem writing out those slips.
